title: R44526
content: The first section of the report outlines the FY2017 judiciary appropriations process, detailing key actions such as the initial request submission, hearings by House and Senate subcommittees, markups by House and Senate Appropriations Committees, House floor consideration of H.R. 5485, and the enactment of the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2017 on May 5, 2017. The status is summarized in Table 1. The Budget for Fiscal Year 2017 was submitted on February 9, 2016, requesting $7.58 billion in new budget authority for judicial branch activities. This includes $6.99 billion in discretionary funds and $0.59 billion in mandatory funding for judges' salaries and benefits. Neither the House nor Senate Appropriations Subcommittees on Financial Services held hearings on the FY2017. The House and Senate Appropriations Subcommittees did not hold hearings on the FY2017 judicial branch budget request. The House subcommittee accepted programmatic and language submissions until March 17, 2016. On May 25, the House Appropriations Committee Subcommittee on Financial Services recommended $7.55 billion in funds for the judiciary, including mandatory funds for judges' salaries and benefits. On June 9, 2016, the House Appropriations Committee recommended the same amount in funds for the judiciary. The committee recommended $7.55 billion in funds for the judiciary, including mandatory funds for judges' salaries and benefits as required under current law. The bill was ordered reported by a vote of 30-18 ( H.R. 5485 , H.Rept. 114-624 ). No amendments were offered related to the judiciary. On June 15, the Senate Appropriations Committee Subcommittee on Financial Services and General Government recommended $7.58 billion in funds for the judiciary. On June 16, 2016, the Senate Appropriations Committee held a markup of the FY2017 FSGG bill. On June 16, 2016, the Senate Appropriations Committee recommended $7.58 billion in funds for the judiciary in the FY2017 FSGG bill. The bill was ordered reported by a vote of 30-0. No amendments were offered related to the judiciary. On July 5, the House agreed to a structured rule for consideration of the Financial Services and General Government bill. One amendment related to the judiciary was made in order to reduce funding to the Salaries and Expenses Account under the Courts of Appeals, District Courts, and other. On July 7, amendment #60 was passed by voice vote as part of H.Amdt. 1246 to increase funding by $1 million for the judiciary. H.R. 5485, as amended, was agreed to with a vote of 239-185. No further action was taken on H.R. 5485 or S. 3067 before FY2017. Judicial branch activities were funded through continuing appropriations resolutions until the enactment of the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2017, which provided $7.5 billion for the judiciary, an increase of $176.2 million. Division E of the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2017 provides $7.5 billion for the judiciary, an increase of $176.2 million from FY2016. This funding is $63.0 million less than the requested amount. The Consolidated Appropriations Act of 2014 provided $7.261 billion for the judiciary, representing a 3.2% increase from FY2014. A funding gap led to a partial government shutdown for 16 days until a CR (P.L. 113-46) was enacted on October 17, 2013, providing funding through January 15, 2014. Following the enactment of a consolidated appropriations bill on January 17, 2014 (P.L. 113-76), $7.039 billion was allocated for the judiciary for FY2014, with approximately 0.2% of total budget authority. The Supreme Court accounts for about 1% of the judiciary budget, with the majority of funds going towards the lower federal courts and related services. The largest account in the judiciary budget for FY2017 is the Salaries and Expenses account for the U.S. Courts of Appeals, District Courts, and Other Judicial Services, covering salaries of judges and necessary court expenses. Other significant accounts include Defender Services and Court Security. The judiciary budget for FY2017 includes funds for Defender Services, Court Security, U.S. Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit, U.S. Court of International Trade, Fees of Jurors and Commissioners, Administrative Office of the U.S. Courts, Federal Judicial Center, U.S. Sentencing Commission, and Judicial Retirement Funds. Specialized courts like the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Armed Forces and the U.S. Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims are funded separately. The judiciary uses non-appropriated funds, primarily from court filing fees, to offset expenses in various accounts such as Courts of Appeals and District Courts. The judiciary uses non-appropriated funds from court filing fees to offset expenses in Courts of Appeals, District Courts, and Other Judicial Services. These funds are considered "unencumbered" and result from savings in areas where budgeted costs did not materialize. The judiciary has limited control over these savings, such as the confirmation rate of judges and budgeting for judgeships, rent costs, and technology funding. The budget request and appropriations figures reflect the net resources for the judiciary. The judiciary's budget includes net resources and "encumbered" funds for specific purposes like office space and technology projects. Cost-containment efforts focus on office space rental, personnel expenses, information technology, and operating costs. Judge Julia S. Gibbons emphasizes these efforts in the FY2017 budget submission. In the FY2017 budget, Judge Julia S. Gibbons highlights the judiciary's cost-containment initiatives, focusing on shared administrative services and reducing space footprint. Efforts aim to address cost growth and reflect policies in place since 2004. The judiciary is reevaluating practices in response to a 2015 GAO report on cost savings. The judiciary, in response to a 2015 GAO report on cost savings, is reevaluating its methodologies for accounting cost reductions. Judge Gibbons reported achieving a nearly $1.5 billion cost reduction over 10 years. The Judicial Conference set a goal of a 3% reduction in total space, with 30% already achieved by March 2015, resulting in $5.8 million in rent savings. The judiciary is on track to accomplish the full three percent reduction by the end of fiscal year 2018. Efforts to improve judicial security have been spurred by recent incidents, including the double homicide of a federal judge's family members in Chicago in 2005, Atlanta courthouse killings in 2005, a state judge shot in his Reno office in 2006, and a shooting at the Lloyd D. George U.S. Courthouse in Las Vegas in 2010. Measures such as providing intrusion detection systems for judges' homes have been implemented. The Court Security Improvement Act of 2007 aimed to enhance security for judges and court personnel, as well as courtroom safety for the public. The judiciary has been working closely with the U.S. Marshals Service to ensure protective policies are in place, including a pilot program for perimeter security at selected courthouses previously under the Federal Protective Service. The US Marshals Service implemented a pilot program in FY2009 to improve perimeter security at selected courthouses previously under the Federal Protective Service. The program, in place at courthouses in Chicago, Detroit, Phoenix, New York, Tucson, and Baton Rouge, is evaluated for enhancements. The Judicial Conference recommended creating 57 new federal judgeships in March 2017. The Judicial Conference recommended creating 57 new federal judgeships in March 2017, with 5 in the courts of appeals and 52 in the district courts. Several bills have been introduced in Congress to create new judgeships, but no final action has been taken. Since 1990, the number of appellate judgeships has remained at 179 according to the Judicial Conference. The number of appellate judgeships has stayed at 179, despite a 40% increase in appellate court case filings. District judgeships increased by 5% to 677, with a 38% rise in district court case filings. The FY2017 judiciary budget request is $7.53 billion, with the Supreme Court requesting $94.5 million for salaries, expenses, and building care. The FY2017 judiciary budget request includes $79.3 million for Salaries and Expenses and $14.9 million for Care of the Building and Grounds, representing a 7.0% increase over FY2016. The budget request for the court with 12 judges is $33.1 million, a 2.1% decrease from FY2016. The court has jurisdiction over various legal matters including patents, trademarks, international trade, and federal claims cases. The FY2017 judiciary budget request includes $20.50 million, a 1.7% increase over FY2016, with $20.46 million provided in P.L. 115-31. The total funding request covers 12 of the 13 courts of appeals and 94 district judicial courts. The judiciary budget request for FY2017 includes funding for 94 district judicial courts across various states and territories. The total funding is divided among different categories such as salaries, court security, defender services, and fees of jurors and commissioners. The House-passed bill allocated $7,104.7 million, the Senate committee-reported bill allocated $7,135.8 million, and P.L. 115-31 provides $7,076.9 million. The FY2017 request is $5,469.8 million, representing a 2.8% increase over the FY2016 enacted level. The Vaccine Injury Compensation Program received $5,420.4 million under P.L. 115-31 to address vaccine tort liability claims. The FY2017 request was $6.3 million, with the House-passed bill and Senate committee-reported bill providing full funding. P.L. 115-31 allocated $6.5 million for protective services and security systems in federal facilities. The FY2017 request for court security funding is $565.4 million, a 5.1% increase from FY2016. The funding is primarily allocated to the U.S. Marshals Service for court security officers. This account also covers the operations of federal public defender and community defender organizations, as well as expenses for private practice panel attorneys appointed by federal courts. The FY2017 request for private practice panel attorneys appointed by federal courts is $1,056.3 million, a 5.1% increase from FY2016. The House-passed bill provided the full request, while the Senate committee-reported bill provided $1,054.5 million. P.L. 115-31 provides $1,044.6 million. This account also funds fees and allowances for jurors and compensation for jury and land commissioners, with a FY2017 request of $43.7 million, a 1.1% decrease from FY2016. The AOUSC budget for FY2017 is $39.9 million, a decrease of 1.1% from FY2016. AOUSC provides administrative and IT services to U.S. courts and supports the Judicial Conference. The FY2017 request for AOUSC is $87.7 million, a 2.4% increase from FY2016. The House bill provided $87.5 million, while the Senate bill provided $39.9 million. The Federal Judicial Center's FY2017 request is $28.3 million, with P.L. 115-31 providing the full amount. The center conducts research, evaluation, and education for the judiciary. The House bill and Senate committee-reported bill also supported the full request. The FY2017 request for the commission is $18.2 million, with P.L. 115-31 providing $18.1 million. This mandatory account funds payments to retired judges and their families. The funding for retirement benefits fluctuates based on estimated costs. The FY2017 request is $161.0 million, which was fully provided for in P.L. 115-31. The law also includes provisions for salaries, expenses, transfers between judiciary accounts, official reception expenses, contracting for repairs, court security pilot program, and a one-year extension. The FY2017 request includes $100,000 for court security pilot program and a one-year extension of certain temporary judgeships.
